content.title: The Neediest Cases; In Student's Success, Mother Sees Many Helping Hands

content.text: The quinceañera photo hangs high up on the living room wall: Wanda Reynoso, at 15, in a sparkling white dress and a tiara, radiant against the pink backdrop.  Ms. Reynoso, now 18, is still the same beautiful girl, but underneath her cocoa skin, her color is yellow and pale.  Subdued and gracious, Ms. Reynoso is fighting a disease that has left her exhausted; the treatments she undergoes have been like a battle.  She has aplastic anemia, a disorder of the bone marrow that causes it to stop producing red and white blood cells, and platelets. ''The inside of the bone is, like, empty,'' she said. ''I'm not producing blood or any type of cells.''  The disease compromises her ability to fight infections. Her bones and joints ache. She is at risk of uncontrolled bleeding. ''If I get a bruise, I got to tell him real quick,'' she said of her doctor's strict instructions.  ''Sometimes I don't even want to wake up,'' she said. ''I feel my body so tired, so heavy. I don't even want to get up from the bed.''  In August, she began chemotherapy at the Children's Hospital at Montefiore in the Bronx, but it was discontinued in October because her body was not responding.  She needs a bone marrow transplant and is waiting for a compatible donor. Neither her mother nor her brother is a match. On Tuesdays and Fridays she takes two trains and a bus from her Bronx apartment to the hospital for blood transfusions. She receives two bags each visit, and the process takes about four hours and leaves her exhausted.  Her doctors worry that public transportation will expose her weakened immune system to infections, but she has no other way to get to the hospital and back. It reassures her that her mother, Fatima Sanchez, goes with her.  If she needs to, Ms. Reynoso can sleep on the train.  No parent could be prepared for such a frightening illness in a child, but for Ms. Sanchez, this has been particularly devastating.  Three years ago, Ms. Sanchez, 44, moved her son, Gregory Reynoso, now 15, and Ms. Reynoso from the Dominican Republic to the Bronx. When Ms. Reynoso became ill, Ms. Sanchez left her restaurant job to care for her daughter full time.  ''Not being able to work has not been easy,'' Ms. Sanchez said in Spanish. ''There have been times when I feel very desperate.'' Her salary was the family's only income. They are legal residents, not citizens, and the family does not qualify for public assistance.  Ms. Reynoso's grandmother and aunts, also in the Bronx, pay the $642 monthly rent on their one-bedroom apartment.  Then there is the language barrier. Ms. Sanchez does not speak English and often relies on her daughter to translate medical information.  ''There's days when she's not even up to speaking, so when she's not up to it, what information does Mom get?'' asked Minerva Cales, a social worker. Ms. Cales works at Ms. Reynoso's high school for the Children's Aid Society, one of seven agencies supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.  In late September, Ms. Cales noticed that Ms. Reynoso, a senior and a strong student, was missing a lot of school. When she learned about the illness behind the absences, Ms. Cales did what she could to help.  Ms. Cales used $1,570.80 in Neediest Cases money for a variety of items: a sofa bed and armchair for the living room; $200 in clothing vouchers ; $80 in MetroCards; $90.89 to pay the bill on a cellphone, which is the family's only phone; and $200 in food vouchers.  With Ms. Cales's help, Ms. Reynoso now has Medicaid, and can be treated at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, where, Ms. Cales said, Ms. Reynoso can be added to a list for a bone marrow donor. Now that she is 18, she is above the age limit at the Children's Hospital, Ms. Cales said.  Ms. Reynoso continues her school work at home, with daily visits from a home educator, and a computer borrowed from the school. ''Even with the illness, she's still up to date on her schoolwork,'' Ms. Cales said.  When Ms. Reynoso talks about dancing, she still sparkles. ''I was the Shakira of the school,'' she said. She won the title after dancing in a school talent show, when she showed off some moves inspired by the pop performer.  Now, Ms. Reynoso's brother sometimes has to carry her up the stairs to their fourth-floor walk-up.  ''She's a senior at school this year, we're hoping that she's able to be there at graduation,'' Ms. Cales said. ''That's my goal.'' content.title: The Neediest Cases; Her Deadly Illness Becomes Her Family's Struggle

content.text: There were two moments when life changed forever for Jennifer Coello.  The first was when her boyfriend, in a rage, held a kitchen knife to her pregnant belly. Still a teenager, she fled her native Ecuador to America, where she lives with relatives in the Bronx.  The second was when her son, Michael, was about to be born in a New York hospital. The doctors told her, she said, ''Your child is going to be born with a problem with his head, and we don't know what it is.''  Today, Michael is a cheerful child, with a bowl haircut, a lopsided smile and a slightly cross-eyed gaze. He cannot talk, and he crawls on his knees.  Ms. Coello, now 24, and Michael, 7, live with her grandparents in a dilapidated apartment building in the Bronx, near Franz Sigel Park. It is two flights up, on the third floor. There is no elevator.  Michael is 80 pounds and because he cannot walk, Ms. Coello must carry him up the stairs, 32 steps in all, his left arm holding on to her neck and his right hand playing with a toy. She catches her breath on the first floor.  Ms. Coello spoke recently in Spanish, which was translated by Silvia Morales, her social worker.  Ms. Coello was born in Guayaquil, Ecuador's largest port and the city from which tourists typically depart for the Galápagos. When she was 16, she became pregnant and lived with her boyfriend's family.  They were poorer than most and there was never enough to eat. Asked if she ever went to bed hungry, Ms. Coello replied, in English, ''Many times.''  She worried about her unborn baby. ''If I'm hungry,'' she recalled thinking, ''then Michael must be hungry.''  Her boyfriend slapped her, flew into mysterious rages, she said. She did not know why. Then, one day, she said she had had enough and wanted to break up with him. He held a knife to her abdomen and told her to never leave him. She was five months pregnant.  Ms. Coello wrote to her grandmother in the Bronx, begging for help. She was sent a plane ticket to America.  Ms. Coello told her boyfriend that she would help him get a visa so he could also come to America. She didn't.  By June 1999, she was 17, pregnant and living with 13 other people in the Bronx apartment she lives in today. (A brother and the families of an aunt and an uncle have since moved out.)  As Ms. Coello was about to go into labor in October 1999 in nearby Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center in the Bronx, doctors detected something troubling. Ultrasound images indicated a growth at the back of Michael's head.  ''We see like a ball, a ball of water,'' Ms. Coello remembers the doctors telling her.  After Michael was born, doctors diagnosed his illness as hydrocephalus, a buildup of excess cerebrospinal fluid, which cushions the brain within the cranium. The excess fluid is present at birth and the body cannot absorb the fluid fast enough, so it must be drained with a shunt, or tube. The buildup can damage the brain, hurting intellectual and physical development.  When Michael was born, Ms. Coello said, ''I saw a real cute boy, as I imagined, but I felt so bad when I saw the back of his head.''  Today, Michael needs special education, as well as physical and occupational therapy, despite regular draining of the excess cerebrospinal fluid.  Last summer, Ms. Coello turned for help to Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, one of seven agencies supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which issued a $102 grant. The money was spent mostly for a used children's wheelchair for Michael. He had outgrown a baby stroller.  But what Ms. Coello really needs is a long-term wheelchair for Michael. She said that such specialized wheelchairs made of alloys light enough for her to lift but strong enough to support Michael as he grows are expensive. They are typically $1,000 to $2,000.  Ms. Coello has little money or free time. She gets some public assistance, and her grandparents, who pay for much of the $920-a-month rent with pension and other payments, can contribute little.  Ms. Coello also received a grant and is studying English. She also enrolled in a program with the ASA Institute of Business and Computer Technology to become a medical technician.  For the moment, she has other concerns. Ms. Coello also used part of the $102 in Neediest Cases money to buy an air mattress, sheets and blankets to replace bedding infested with bedbugs, which remain a problem in the apartment.  When Ms. Coello goes to sleep at night, what does she think about? ''I wonder,'' she said, ''how many bug bites I'm going to wake up with.'' content.title: The Neediest Cases; Mother Flees To America, Only to Face New Struggle

content.text: When William McKinney showed up at church one Sunday more than a decade ago, he said he was open to anything that would help him make a fresh start.  At the time, Mr. McKinney was running away from a life he had built and lost in Texas. His first marriage had failed, and after a brief period of homelessness, he had returned to Brooklyn, where he was raised.  That Sunday, the simplicity and the practicality of the sermon at Bible Faith Tabernacle, a nondenominational church on St. John's Place in Bedford-Stuyvesant, appealed to him.  ''The teaching was something,'' he said. ''It taught about responsibility, it taught about stuff that you should learn when you're growing up, but everybody doesn't.''  He returned there, week after week, and soon learned that the church was looking for a maintenance man. In search of work, he took the job.  Today, Mr. McKinney, 40, is still responsible for the church's maintenance. But over time, his role as a member of the congregation evolved. Now a deacon, he runs the church's food pantry and is a sound technician during services.  He learned graphics design and created bulletins and fliers on the church's computers. In a church office, called the ''video suite,'' he spends hours each week in front of television and computer screens producing videos of his pastor's sermons, which are shown on local cable-access channels.  He also met his second wife among the congregation of 300, and in 2001, their daughter, Ájee, was born. His church has been the place ''that really upheld me,'' he said. ''My mind wasn't working properly and the church was the one thing that kept my sanity, gave me a sense of purpose, that it's worth being around.''  The church remains Mr. McKinney's haven. And perhaps out of gratitude, or maybe a sense of obligation, he said, he does not want to leave his maintenance job there even if his video-production skills may command a higher salary elsewhere.  But about two years ago, when problems developed between him and his wife and she moved out, he was left to support his daughter alone. His salary at the church was not enough to pay the bills. In addition to caring for Ájee, he was paying $500 a month in child support to his first wife in Texas to help care for their teenage daughter.  By last summer, he had fallen months behind on the rent for his apartment in Bedford-Stuyvesant, and KeySpan had turned off his gas. At first, he improvised by cooking meals in the microwave. But when he lost his electricity as well, he could not care for his daughter there.  He and Ájee moved into his mother's apartment in Crown Heights for several days. He tried not to let on to his daughter how serious their financial situation had become.  ''I told her there was a problem with the lights and that I was going to take care of it,'' he said. ''I told her to kind of keep it quiet; don't tell everybody the lights are out.''  Meanwhile, Mr. McKinney found odd jobs and freelance graphics and video work. With help from public assistance, he restored his electricity within a week and took his daughter back home.  For help with his gas bill, he turned to Catholic Charities, Diocese of Brooklyn and Queens, one of the seven agencies supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. A caseworker there negotiated with KeySpan to waive the late charges he had accrued and restore his gas service for $199.53, using money provided by Neediest Cases.  Public assistance grants helped him pay the rent and narrowly avoid eviction. Now, he is living paycheck to paycheck, he said, but he and Ájee have the necessities.  ''A year ago, I was working on having a place to stay. That was the immediate goal, the long term, the short term,'' he said. But now, he added, he is thinking about goals for 5 and 10 years ahead.  ''It's not a good thing when you get to, like, 40 years old, and you realize it's not a game,'' he said. ''I think that that happens to people, and it happened to me.''  Mr. McKinney said he knew he must increase his income and begin a savings plan. Those were demands his wife had made as well. In November, having talked through some of their problems, his wife agreed to move back in with him. Since then, they have been meeting with their bishop for counseling.  ''I love my wife, and I love my daughter,'' Mr. McKinney said. ''I want to see the American dream, the picket fence.'' content.title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY

content.text: Sally Mae Jenkins is full of stories. In a breathless rasp, she recalls traipsing through the woods of her native South Carolina, running from snakes and getting into dicey escapades with her 13 brothers and sisters. Then she talks of having a daughter at 17, only to lose her 25 years later. Each reverie is delivered in her thick-as-molasses Southern accent and punctuated with ''Lord have mercy!''  ''I spend hours just listening to her stories,'' said Ramona Diaz, a counselor at the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, where Ms. Jenkins, who is mentally retarded, has spent 30 hours a week for the last 22 years.  As the words spilled out of Ms. Jenkins, a curse word, or half of one, came out, prompting Elina Mushinskaya, the program's coordinator, to remark on her tendency to populate her yarns with profanity. ''She's toned it down some,'' she said.  Ms. Jenkins replied, ''I caught myself.''  Memories pour out Ms. Jenkins at a breakneck speed, the past and present bumping up against each other. Ms. Jenkins, a small woman who looks younger than her 58 years, told about how she had moved to Brooklyn to be with her sister in the 1980s after the death of their mother, who had been caring for her.  Then Ms. Jenkins started to talk about her daughter, Janet, who died in 1990 from complications from a seizure disorder at age 25.  ''I had a daughter but I lost her. She said, 'Good night, Ma.' She told me that night when she was going to bed, 'I won't be here that long,' and that's it.''  The next morning Ms. Jenkins could not wake her daughter and she called for an ambulance.  Ms. Jenkins went to the hospital with her sister, Mary Jackson. Ms. Jenkins said that something told her not to go into her daughter's room. ''Oh Lord, my baby's going to leave me, Mary,'' Ms. Jenkins had told her sister.  Janet is buried in Cypress Hills cemetery in Brooklyn, a location, Ms. Jenkins insisted, that was chosen by her daughter.  '''If something happens to me, mom, bury me there,' '' Ms. Jenkins remembered her daughter saying. She scolded her daughter for even entertaining the thought.  Ms. Jenkins's eyes grow moist as she neared the end of her story. ''And that's what happened, and that's all,'' she said.  But today, Ms. Jenkins is not alone. She goes to work every day at the Brooklyn Center, earning a stipend for performing a variety of tasks, such as stuffing inserts into shopping bags for college bookstores. She gets paid by volume, about $6 or $7 per box of bags. Ms. Jenkins completes about three boxes a day.  Ms. Jenkins also receives about $500 per month from Social Security and about $100 in food stamps.  She lives with her sister in Bushwick among a revolving door of her sister's visiting grandchildren.  Also sharing the apartment is Ms. Jenkins's boyfriend, Ed, who also attends the Brooklyn Center. When asked about her 15-year romance, she declined to discuss it.  ''I don't want to tell none of his business,'' she said.  But she will talk about anything else. ''I got a lot of friends,'' she said, counting them off on her fingers.  She quickly shifted gears and said that she likes to cook oxtail, spareribs, chicken with stuffing and collard greens with mustard. And though it is not good for her asthma and conflicts with the medications she takes for a heart murmur, she drinks beer.  ''Not every day,'' she assured Ms. Mushinskaya, who had cast a worried glance in her direction.  Despite her disability, Ms. Jenkins retains a streak of independence, walking two hours in the morning and two hours in the evening on her commute from Bushwick to the Brooklyn Center, in downtown Brooklyn.  She is something of a favorite of the supervisors at the center, and she rarely offers them any complaints. So when the weather turned cold Ms. Mushinskaya, aware of Ms. Jenkins's preference for walking, asked her if there was anything she needed. Yes, Ms. Jenkins said, she needed a coat.  The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund supplied $49.99 to allow her to buy a brown coat, with a hood and a dark faux-fur collar, that cinches at Ms. Jenkins's small waist. On the first cold day of the year, Ms. Jenkins shuffled out into the frigid sunshine and shoved her hands into the pockets, smiling proudly.  Several of her friends at the center joined her.  ''She's always on the go,'' Ms. Diaz said. It was Ms. Diaz who had accompanied Ms. Jenkins to the Burlington Coat Factory and helped her choose her coat.  After showing off her prized possession, Ms. Jenkins waved to no one in particular. Then she bid the small crowd adieu. ''O.K., got to go back to work,'' she said, and went inside. content.title: The Neediest Cases; A Warm Coat for a Woman With Endless Stories to Tell

content.text: Margaret Silvestri stopped getting out of bed altogether when her son was about 11 years old. She had been experiencing symptoms of depression for years, but this was a breakdown. Her son, Mark Silvestri, called relatives for help.  ''She started to scream and cry,'' Mr. Silvestri, now 26, said. ''She was thinking I was calling them to get her.'' But he made the calls, he said, mostly because there was no food in the apartment and he did not know what to do.  As her depression worsened, Ms. Silvestri spent her days shedding quiet tears, leaving her son to cook for himself. Their apartment was rarely cleaned.  ''I was always crying,'' Ms. Silvestri, now 53, recalled of the time before her breakdown. ''I knew something was wrong.''  After her son called for help, Ms. Silvestri was hospitalized at Jacobi Medical Center for several weeks in 1991. Meanwhile, her son stayed with his aunt and uncle for months, realizing how different life could be outside his mother's Bronx apartment.  In her life, Ms. Silvestri had suffered a number of medical problems, yet it was only depression that seemed overwhelming, she said.  She was born prematurely and soon received a diagnosis of hydrocephalus, an abnormal buildup of fluid on the brain. She was 8 months old when she had surgery to correct the problem. She was also born blind in her right eye.  Nevertheless, she played softball as a child, though her father refused to watch her games out of fear that she would get hurt, she said.  When she became depressed in her late teens, Ms. Silvestri said she thought about suicide and twice asked her brother to take her to a hospital before she harmed herself.  To cope with her depression, she went into counseling. Meanwhile, she took typing and business math courses and eventually got a job at a Manhattan insurance company and an apartment in the Bronx.  But, at 27, her depression returned after she gave birth to her son. Four years later, it got worse after she had a second child, whom she gave up for adoption.  With the help of medications her doctors prescribed, Ms. Silvestri said she seemed to move beyond her depression at times, but it returned periodically, and her struggle left little structure for her growing son.  By the time Mr. Silvestri reached his teenage years, he often refused to go to school and his temper would flare violently, she said.  ''He was always angry,'' Ms. Silvestri remembered. ''I couldn't understand why.''  Unsure of how to help him, Ms. Silvestri sent her son, then 13, to live at Children's Village, a boarding home in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., where he remained for about two years.  When he returned to live with her, his anger had subsided and their relationship improved, but their peace was short-lived. In 1999 they were evicted from their apartment after falling behind in rent and had to leave most of their possessions behind.  Afterward, they spent two years in a Brooklyn shelter and then another two years in a shelter in the Bronx, in each sharing a single bedroom.  During that time, Ms. Silvestri began experiencing mood swings. At one point she called the police on her son, who was forced to move out of the shelter and live with friends for a while.  In 2003 she was diagnosed with bipolar disorder at Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center, where she remained for treatment for two months.  In the meantime, her son, who had since returned to live at the shelter, had secured steady work with a general contractor. He later decided to get his own apartment, and he also pulled away from Ms. Silvestri emotionally.  When Ms. Silvestri was ready to leave the hospital, social workers there helped her secure a room at Metro House on University Avenue in the Bronx, which serves once homeless, mentally ill people and is run by the Metropolitan Council on Jewish Poverty. The council is affiliated with the UJA-Federation of New York, one of seven agencies supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.  Ms. Silvestri has furnished her small room at Metro House with a telephone, a television and a small refrigerator with income from Social Security disability and the help of her son, who was married in 2004 and has slowly begun to reach out to her. She shares a bathroom and kitchen with other residents on her floor.  On her walls, she has taped up pictures of her relatives and a certificate of membership to her nearby church, where she is an usher.  This winter, social workers at Metro House helped Ms. Silvestri buy warm clothing, including a coat, with $300 from Neediest Cases.  ''I'm comfortable, I'm happy to be here,'' Ms. Silvestri said, adding that she could not afford an apartment and that she knows living with her son is not an option.  Ms. Silvestri said she would like to talk to him more often.  ''I was a half-good mother and a half-bad mother,'' she said, but added that her son has not been unforgiving. ''He told me at one point he understood what I was going through as a single mother; that it was hard.'' content.title: Corrections

content.text: Cassandra Bogen returned to Jamaica, Queens, from North Carolina in 1998 to take care of her dying mother. Being in her childhood home brought back a flood of memories.  She remembered her sister learning to play the piano. And she remembered that it was at Martin Van Buren High School in Queens Village where she fell in love with her first boyfriend. Though the relationship ended, they had a daughter, Twanysha, now 15.  Ms. Bogen said watching her mother, Marie Bogen, slowed down by age and illness was a stark contrast to the happier times they shared when she was younger.  When Ms. Bogen was a child, the holidays, even on her mother's limited budget as an accounts payable clerk in a grocery store, were always festive. ''No matter what, if you were in my mother's home you talked and enjoyed yourself,'' said Ms. Bogen, now 34, in her living room recently.  As diabetes eroded her mother's strength, the bills began to pile up. To pay the bills, Ms. Bogen worked as a consumer service representative at Health Insurance Plan of New York, and later at Bell Atlantic, which became Verizon. ''I just worked to support my mom, help with rent, groceries and bills,'' she said.  Ms. Bogen also helped her sister, Sonia Fryer, financially. Ms. Fryer has Crohn's disease and was also recovering from radiation treatment for a brain tumor.  Following her mother's example, Ms. Bogen said she was unequivocal when it came to family matters. ''Family comes first; material things are not important,'' she said.  In the last year of her mother's life, Ms. Bogen was happy to see her mother spend time with her grandson, Amir, who was born in May 2001. Twanysha was especially close to her grandmother, and insisted on sleeping in her bed. She was in the bedroom when her grandmother died on Nov. 23, 2001.  After her mother's death, Ms. Bogen took over the expenses and the apartment and was further strained financially. She scraped together $6,000 through a loan, her 401(k) plan, and family and friends to pay for her mother's funeral expenses.  In 2003, she left Verizon, taking a voluntary severance package, which she used to finish her bachelor's degree in business administration at Metropolitan College of New York. With the degree, she thought she would have a better chance of earning a higher salary. But even after she graduated, she could only find full-time work without benefits.  By 2005, her rent increased to $940 from $839 a month. She was working on Long Island in the customer service department at Health Care Partners, earning $15 an hour. The commuting and the stress began to wear her down. She was hospitalized in December 2005 for severe migraines, she said.  In the spring of 2006, her rent was increased again, this time to $1,053.49. It could not have happened at a worse time. She was fired from her job, and her daughter was acting out at school. Twanysha was in therapy for four months to work through severe depression and feelings of abandonment from her father and grandmother. ''All she understands is that people were in her life and now they are not,'' Ms. Bogen said.  ''I felt that I was not doing my job as a parent,'' Ms. Bogen added. ''You are doing so much and your plate is overfull, but you're trying to accommodate their needs.''  When rent was due in May 2006, Ms. Bogen was short. ''I had to fight to maintain a roof over their head; she needed stability,'' Ms. Bogen said of her daughter. ''I definitely didn't want to go into the shelter.''  While trying to find work, she received $164 a week from unemployment, which barely covered the cost of food, much less rent. She turned off her cellphone and posted a notice in the laundry room of her building to sell her love seat, sofa and television.  ''Nobody was calling me for jobs, I didn't have food stamps,'' she said. ''I was desperate.'' She sold the furnishings for $1,850, she said, which was about a third of what she had paid for them.  Trying to head off eviction, she went to a housing court in Queens in July 2006. There she received a number for the Community Service Society of New York, which is one of the seven agencies supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Anna Auleley, a caseworker at the agency, returned her call and said she could help as soon as Ms. Bogen found a job, to ensure that she could pay rent the next month.  By September 2006, she owed $5,485.32. ''My management company would not let me pay a partial amount; I had to pay in full,'' she said. Before time ran out, she found a data entry job in New Jersey making $15 an hour. To pay the outstanding amount, Ms. Auleley drew $1,581.83 from Neediest Cases and received $1,053.49 from FEMA. Ms. Bogen covered the rest with her savings.  ''It was a big load off my shoulders,'' Ms. Bogen said with a sigh of relief.  Ms. Bogen now works temporarily in data processing for Fidelis Care in Queens, making $13 an hour. And she is sending out résumés, seeking an administrative position.  Now in her apartment, beside the piano her sister used to play (one of the few things she did not sell), is a worn sofa and love seat given to her by a neighbor.  ''I wasn't going to say no,'' she said, referring to the offer for the furniture. ''For today, this is how we get by.'' content.title: The Neediest Cases; A Mother Dreams of Job Security, and an End to Scraping By

content.text: ''Blood'' is spray painted over the front door of the apartment building where Patricia Barnes's family lives. It appears again and again on the walls of the stairwell leading to their second-floor apartment.  Ms. Barnes, 38, is raising two teenagers in the tough East New York neighborhood in Brooklyn, and she is doing everything she can to keep them off these streets.  About five years ago, she sent her four younger children, now ages 11 to 13, to live with their father's extended family in Ivory Coast, where she believed they would be safer.  ''I think that is the best decision I made,'' said Ms. Barnes, who calls Ivory Coast to speak with her children two or three times a week. ''The way things are running around out here nowadays, I don't want them out here. I don't want him out here.''  By ''him,'' Ms. Barnes meant her son Raymond, 14, who is a high school freshman. Her daughter Chaka Ward, 17, who prefers to be called Tisha, is a sophomore.  Ms. Barnes said she began seeing worrisome changes in Raymond when he was in junior high school.  ''He was doing pretty good in school, and then, I don't know,'' Ms. Barnes said. ''It's like he woke up and he just, 'I don't want to do it no more.' ''  Raymond agreed. ''I was a loose cannon,'' he said, adding that he was ''running wild.''  He was skipping school, outside at all hours, quick-tempered and willing to fight. Such behavior would be frustrating for any parent, but for Ms. Barnes, who sometimes hears gunfire from her window, it was frightening. She waited up for him at night. She worried that despite his youth, Raymond's height -- at 14 he is already 6-foot-3 -- might get him in adult-sized trouble.  ''It felt like my whole world was crumbling,'' she said. ''I was losing control of him, and that's the one thing I felt should never, ever happen.''  Ms. Barnes took any help she could find, including a warning from Raymond's basketball coach that bad behavior would keep him on the bench.  ''She slowed me down, started making me think,'' Raymond said about his coach. ''I really wanted to be on the team. So I started calming down, letting a lot of things slide.''  But Raymond's behavior did not change overnight. An altercation at school led to more absences, and in December 2005, Ms. Barnes applied for a Person In Need of Supervision petition. The petition would give Family Court the power to force Raymond to attend school.  Rather than grant the petition, the court referred the family for counseling at the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, one of seven agencies supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.  They began attending counseling sessions in February at the bureau's East New York Family Center. Ms. Barnes goes weekly, and Tisha and Raymond accompany her monthly.  After 10 months of counseling, changes are evident in Ms. Barnes's life. She is training for a new job and earned her G.E.D. last month.  Ms. Barnes had worked as a home health aide for years, but it was unstable income, and she relied on public assistance to make ends meet.  In October, Ms. Barnes started a job training program through public assistance. She works for the Parks Department, cleaning city parks. She describes the program as ''giving you your responsibility: to be a part of the working class,'' she said, ''which is a beautiful thing, because I love it.''  She earns about $320 a week and receives $115 in food stamps each month. Her share of the rent for her subsidized four-bedroom apartment is $150 a month. Her job training program ends in March, and she hopes to be hired permanently.  Ms. Barnes said she cherished the time she spent with her oldest children studying for the G.E.D. exam. Tisha helped her with language, and Raymond studied algebra with her.  ''He actually took a genuine interest in it,'' Ms. Barnes said. ''It was so amazing for us to just lay across the bed and just talk about it.''  ''I'm proud of my accomplishments,'' she said. ''Your kids have something to look up to.''  Cascille Andela, a social worker who counsels the family, said she had seen a big change in Ms. Barnes's ability to cope with adversity.  ''She is able to come home and be more relaxed, understanding, and trying to work though problems rather than getting frustrated and throwing her hands up,'' Ms. Andela said.  After a home visit in which she noticed that Raymond and Ms. Barnes were both sleeping in the living room, Ms. Andela used $965 from the Neediest Cases to replace the family's worn mattresses.  ''You've got to have a bed to sleep in,'' Ms. Andela said. ''You can't go to work the next morning if you can't get to sleep at night.''  Ms. Barnes hopes that her children will draw inspiration from her efforts. In December, Tisha started her first job, working at a day care center. ''I don't care where she worked as long as the little girl knows it's going to feel good to get a paycheck,'' Ms. Barnes said.  As for Raymond, he is getting in fewer fights, and is working at grade level for the first time after eight years in special education classes, where he had been placed because of his behavior. He grudgingly admits this year's schoolwork is a little more interesting. Ms. Barnes and Ms. Andela are still working on persuading him to attend school regularly, but he is no longer roaming the streets.  Bit by bit, Ms. Barnes and her family seem to be gaining ground.  ''I've made it my business to not let anything stop me from achieving my goals,'' she said. content.title: The Neediest Cases; A Single Mother Takes Charge, Trading Helplessness for Ambition

content.text: Jill Rappaport had just finished talking to her son, Alex, who is a freshman at Duke University, when she read an article about Steguer Wilson, a young man from the Bronx adjusting to his first semester at Hunter College.  The article told how Mr. Wilson, 18, had received help from the Children's Aid Society, one of seven agencies supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.  Mr. Wilson's story was like that of so many other college freshman. In the beginning of his first year, he was a little overwhelmed by homework, the scheduling of classes and the costs of course materials. Mrs. Rappaport, of Westchester County, decided to help.  ''My son was going through the same things, but I couldn't imagine what it would be like for someone who does not have a supportive community and financial resources,'' she said last month before a board meeting of Children's Aid.  Soon after she read the article on Nov. 13, she wrote a note with a check for $5,000 to the society and specified that the money should help a student like Mr. Wilson, but preferably Mr. Wilson himself.  C. Warren Moses, the chief executive of the society, said, ''This is the kind of generosity that makes the difference in people's lives.''  He called Mrs. Rappaport and invited her to present the check in person to Mr. Wilson at the society's end-of-year board meeting.  ''All the stars were aligned,'' she said. During the board meeting on Dec. 21, Mrs. Rappaport sat by Mr. Wilson, who was wearing a brown striped shirt and matching tie.  Cathleen Clements, the society's director of office of public policy and client advocacy, talked of the importance of the Neediest Cases and said that through it the society's staff had made a difference to nearly 4,600 families during the past nine years.  Mrs. Clements also said that money from Neediest Cases enables the society to help families so they can focus on building strong and healthy lives. When families do not have many resources, even ambitious people like Mr. Wilson can get discouraged.  ''They still need a boost up,'' Mrs. Clements said. ''What we can do with Neediest money is to move them into a place so that they have access to another way of life.''  It was through the society's after-school programs at the Dunlevy Milbank Community Center that Mr. Wilson received support and encouragement.  He participated in capoeira, a Brazilian martial art that incorporates dance, and other programs that helped him get an internship at NBC and the Federal Reserve Bank.  ''Steguer was one of those young people that took advantage of everything,'' said Casper Lassiter, assistant director of youth development and teen programs at the Dunlevy Milbank center. ''It takes a person who knows that they are a leader to step away from the crowd. He is an independent young man and definitely focused.''  At the meeting, Mr. Lassiter played a video about Mr. Wilson that was produced by The New York Times for nytimes.com.  He then introduced Mrs. Rappaport, who presented the $5,000 check. As an added surprise, she gave Mr. Wilson an iPod from her son, who is 18, which he had filled with all his favorite songs.  ''My son hopes that you like some of his music, too,'' she said.  Mr. Wilson was overjoyed. ''I can't believe all this is happening to me,'' he said after the presentation. The money will be put in the bank for future college expenses, he said.  ''I am definitely going to save it,'' he said, ''because I am sure I will have to take out loans if I transfer to a different school'' based on what area of study he chooses.  As for the future, he hopes to make his parents proud, to be successful and to give back to the Children's Aid Society.  ''It would be crazy not to,'' Mr. Wilson said. ''I will definitely give back to the Children's Aid Society; I don't know how I couldn't. They have given me everything.'' content.title: The Neediest Cases; Student Gets Some Help From a Sympathetic Mother

content.text: Life is tight in the small apartment. Tight physically. Tight financially. But there is still room for large aspirations.  ''I want to have combined majors in mechanical and computer engineering and a minor in business,'' Dorichel Rodriguez, a high school senior and one of two teenage daughters living in the apartment with their mother, said recently.  Sitting at a table in the compact living room, Dorichel, 17, told of having completed applications to 15 colleges, including three in the Ivy League, and of beginning the suspenseful wait to hear from them.  ''I want to be a robotics technician,'' she said. ''I'm interested in artificial intelligence.''  Her sister, Marielle, 15, a high school freshman, said she did not know what kind of career she wanted, though she likes astronomy and aerospace engineering. In any case, she is sure she wants to go to college.  Next to her on the couch, their mother, Dorila Rodriguez, 57, a factory worker who speaks only Spanish, said through Dorichel that she wanted her daughters to have college educations so that they would be able to support themselves, ''no matter what happens.''  The couch is where Dorila Rodriquez sleeps in the one-bedroom apartment in Hamilton Heights, a neighborhood in Upper Manhattan immediately south of Washington Heights. The daughters use the bedroom, sleeping in a bunk bed. The kitchen is tiny.  Ms. Rodriguez and her daughters immigrated from the Dominican Republic in 1998, joining Ms. Rodriguez's husband -- the girls' father -- who came to the United States earlier. The couple have since divorced, and Ms. Rodriguez and her daughters have had to make limited means go a long way.  Ms. Rodriguez said that she brought home less than $1,000 a month, after taxes, from her job at a factory that produces body care products. The family gets nearly $300 worth of government food stamps each month, and more than half the total of about $1,300 goes to pay the $738 a month rent.  Dorichel's earnings from two after-school jobs -- a total of about 10 hours a week at $7.50 an hour -- help a little, and the family has Medicaid coverage for doctors' bills. But unforeseen expenses can still be hard to deal with, as in one recent instance.  Ms. Rodriguez and her daughters have the status of noncitizen residents of the country, and in August, Dorichel discovered that she had lost her resident alien card, the important document known as a green card, which permits noncitizens to live and work legally in the United States. The family did not have the $260 in fees needed to replace it, and the Children's Aid Society, one of seven agencies supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, tapped the fund to cover the fees.  This short-term aid was only one of the ways that Children's Aid has played a role in the family's life. Both daughters participate in the organization's Hope Leadership Academy, an after-school program that is based in East Harlem and draws teenagers, mainly from Upper Manhattan and the Bronx, with its educational, cultural and recreational programs.  It also offers its participants training to become peer educators, a role in which they lead workshops and give talks at school and community group sites on subjects like sex education, drug abuse, gang violence and racism.  Dorichel joined the leadership program after learning about it during her freshman year at Manhattan Center for Science and Mathematics, a public high school, also in East Harlem, where Children's Aid is among the organizations that collaborate on a variety of after-school programs.  As a peer educator in the Hope Leadership program, Dorichel conducts a weekly session on sex education and pregnancy prevention. She thinks she can be more effective than an adult in getting the points across, she said, because the teenage audiences ''relate to me more than to an adult.''  Recently, she won a $5,000 community service grant for the program from the New York Jets. She said she would use the money for items like books and videos and possibly to organize a conference on sex education in which groups that focus on the issue would participate.  Marielle became involved with the leadership program last year, while still in middle school, and takes its culinary, dance and drama classes. Both sisters have separately gone on group trips to Germany that the program organizes and that organizations in Germany pay for.  Dorichel said the trip to Germany was a ''great experience'' that showed her the commonalities of teenagers in different cultures.  ''It's a different country and a different language,'' she said, ''but I found that a lot of them are into hip-hop.'' content.title: The Neediest Cases; Mother and Two Teenagers Make the Most of Cramped Spaces and Unlimited Goals

content.text: It was like going through the looking glass. Not long ago, Brenda Francis, who had worked in shelters helping the homeless, found her world turned upside down when she and her teenage son, Bryant Dukes, were suddenly left without a home.  It was a result of a chain of unfortunate events, spiraling out of control from the heart attack and sudden death in 2003 of Maurice Dukes, 51, her longtime partner and the father of her two children. ''He died the day after Valentine's Day,'' recalled Ms. Francis, 50.  They met as teenagers in the early '70s in fairy tale style on the Grand Concourse in the Bronx, outside the building where Ms. Francis, then in high school, lived with her sisters and her mother, who worked for the Port Authority. Ms. Francis fondly remembered the diner her grandparents owned on Linden Boulevard in Queens, George's, where James Brown's son used to eat.  After Ms. Francis graduated, she joined the Army Reserve. In 1975, she and Mr. Dukes had a daughter, Shartel Dukes, who now has a family of her own.  Brenda Francis always knew that she wanted to help people. Throughout her career, she enjoyed steady employment as the office manager at Volunteers of America, a shelter in the Bronx, and at several other shelters. She also worked as a consultant, helping nonprofit organizations set up their tax exemption status. Mr. Dukes received disability assistance because of kidney problems.  Their son, Bryant, now 14, is an eighth grader. He loves basketball and hopes to become a graphic designer. Bryant started off in preschool and kindergarten at a private school, which both mother and son remember fondly as a rigorous environment where he was taught French and Spanish. But at $4,000 a year, Ms. Francis could not continue to pay.  The family lived in Manhattan, on Riverside Drive and 135th Street, until a young woman was raped and murdered in their building. Seeking secure and affordable housing, they moved from borough to borough until settling in the Bronx in 1996.  After Mr. Dukes's death, Ms. Francis slipped into depression and, with less income, fell behind on the rent. The family had little savings. What they did have paid for Mr. Duke's burial. ''He still doesn't have a tombstone,'' Ms. Francis said.  Although they never wed, Ms. Francis called Mr. Dukes her husband. She said the reason she did not marry was her feminist politics. ''Back then I didn't believe in marriage,'' she said, noting that if they had married, she would have been better protected financially.  To cushion the downward spiral that she felt coming, she put the family's belongings -- the contents of six rooms -- into storage, while she and Bryant went to stay in the home of a friend, a pastor. She thought the situation would allow her to get back on her feet.  Instead, Ms. Francis said that she found the lifestyle unsuitable for her son, and in September 2004 they moved to a Bronx shelter.  What was strange about her plunge, she said, was that she had heard the same story many times from people she had counseled. Citing the difficulties of negotiating the welfare system, Ms. Francis said that shortly after arriving at the shelter, she found a two-bedroom apartment with a big kitchen, and hoped to relocate by putting her shelter assistance toward it. ''I like to cook,'' she said. ''It was the nicest place I'd seen for this neighborhood.''  Although the apartment met all of the transfer guidelines, Ms. Francis said, her application was denied.  Ms. Francis and Bryant transferred to Volunteers of America, where she had worked and where she felt safer. There, her old energy kicked in and she started doing taxes for other shelter residents. ''All I brought was my old trusty word processor,'' she said.  By June 2005, Ms. Francis had saved some money and found an apartment in the Wakefield section of the Bronx. But when she and her son got to their new home, they slept on the floor because they did not have the $850 needed to retrieve their belongings from storage, having received only $250 in public assistance.  Ms. Francis contacted Community Service Society of New York, one of the affiliate charities of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The fund came to the rescue with $600 to help her rebuild her home.  Finding a safe and nurturing place for her son remains a challenge, she said, calling the public high schools in the neighborhood ''places I wouldn't send my dogs and cats to.''  Ms. Francis is more determined than ever to help. ''I'm going to run for office to make a difference,'' she said. ''I want to change welfare and stop the throwing away of taxpayer money.''  Back on her feet, operating an administrative business out of her home office, Ms. Francis said she was planning to run for the State Assembly in 2008. ''It happens,'' she said. ''You never know.'' content.title: Will Chuck See His Shadow? First, He Has to Get Used to the Commute

content.text: Growing up in Nepal, Kunsang Sherpa, 23, knew what it was like to go without. His family farmed for a living, but in the mountainous landscape they grew only enough crops to eat. They mostly went without money and without medical care.  For one of his brothers, Dawa, who is a year younger, it was especially hard. Dawa is hearing impaired and did not learn sign language, and there were no special schools for him to attend. He primarily communicated with his brother in a language only they understood.  His deafness, the result of an infection that was never treated, was seen by the traditional Buddhist community around them as a sort of karmic payback for bad deeds in a past life.  His brother's hardships inspired Mr. Sherpa to pursue a career in medicine.  ''That's why I feel I want to be a doctor, or a nurse,'' he said. ''So when I go back to my country, I can help.''  In his efforts to help his brother, Mr. Sherpa met an American couple, Matthew Brodsky, a doctor, and Irene Taylor Brodsky, a journalist, who included Dawa in a book about the deaf community in Nepal, which was published in 1997. The couple helped the Sherpa brothers enroll in schools in Katmandu, the capital. It is a full day's drive from their home in Tarkeyghyang, a region in the Himalayas that Mr. Sherpa generally refers to, in his uncertain English, as ''my place.''  Mr. Sherpa also began working with the couple and a local doctor, helping to set up traveling clinics in even the most rural areas around the country, translating for the doctors and advertising for the clinics. Mr. Sherpa even helped Dr. Brodsky bring a clinic to ''his place,'' getting hundreds of patients to come.  His ability to help organize the clinic still impresses Ms. Brodsky, as does Mr. Sherpa's desire to become a doctor and his constant striving toward that goal. ''Kunsang realizes he is surrounded by people who have more obstacles than he does,'' she said. ''He realizes there is nothing standing in his way.''  But his association with Americans ultimately put him in danger. In Nepal, Western tourists and workers can be the targets of those seeking money, even dangerous groups who will do whatever they can to get it. Mr. Sherpa became a target as well, and was threatened and ultimately beaten after he refused to help a group of men that approached him several times, asking for money.  After he was attacked, in 2004, Mr. Sherpa decided that it was too dangerous for him to stay and that he should come to the United States. With help from the Brodskys, he applied for a travel visa, Ms. Brodsky bought him a plane ticket and he arrived in August of that year. For six months, he lived with the Brodskys in Oregon. With legal help and support from the Brodskys, he applied for political asylum.  Though he enjoyed living there, Mr. Sherpa decided to come to New York, which has a larger Nepalese community. But he could not work until he was granted political asylum, and that occurred in June.  Once it was granted, he realized he would need assistance in finding a job that could cover his expenses, including his $300 a month rent in the two-bedroom apartment in Queens he shares with three roommates. Information from the immigration office led him to Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, one of seven beneficiaries of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. He enrolled in its employment and training program.  He found a job for $11 an hour in the mailroom of a law firm in Manhattan and started work on Dec. 4.  He is in charge of sorting and handing out an entire floor's mail, a job he performs alone.  And alone is how Mr. Sherpa sometimes feels in New York City in general, despite the big apartment buildings and the crowded trains. His mother died a few months ago, and now he worries about his father and brother.  ''In my country, you know everyone. But here, you don't know who lives next door,'' he said. ''If you want to share your feelings, everyone is busy.''  In addition to his job, Mr. Sherpa will enroll in a certified nursing assistant's program, the first step for a career in medicine. Catholic Charities drew on $995 from the fund for the program, which will begin in the spring. In the meantime, Mr. Sherpa volunteers at Elmhurst Hospital Center in Queens.  He is grateful for the help he has received, and, in keeping with his Buddhist beliefs, it reaffirms his commitment to someday giving back.  ''If you want to have a good thing in the next life, you have to do good in this life,'' he said. After he works hard to improve his status, financially and otherwise, he said, ''I can help other people. That's how it works. It's a good thing.''
